Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: A routine, optional daily prayer service is scheduled.
Story: I glanced at the clock as I finished rinsing the dye from my client’s hair. The soft chime of the salon’s doorbell reminded me that the daily prayer service at the chapel would begin in fifteen minutes. My hands trembled slightly as I towel-dried her hair, trying to focus on the present. She peered into the mirror, her lips pressed into a thin line. “It’s… not quite what I expected,” she said quietly, her eyes searching mine for reassurance or a solution. As a hairdresser, I knew I should listen, offer to adjust the colour, and make sure she left happy. But as a priest, I felt the weight of my community’s expectation—my presence at the prayer service, even if optional, brought comfort to many. My mind raced, torn between staying to fix her hair and slipping away to the chapel. I could see her disappointment, and I could almost hear the echo of the chapel’s bell, calling me to serve. My heart pounded as I stood between two worlds, each demanding a part of me I wasn’t sure I could give.
